page.title: Amira Abase, Shamima Begum and Kadiza Sultana

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} '''Amira Abase''', '''Shamima Begum''' and '''Kadiza Sultana''' are three British schoolgirls from the [[Bethnal Green Academy]] in London who left home in February 2015 to join the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL). According to the [[Institute for Strategic Dialogue]] an estimated 550 women and girls from Western countries have travelled to join the Islamic State as of 2015<ref name="TMDUPGIP">{{cite book|last1=Saltman|first1=Erin Marie |last2=Smith |first2=Melanie |title='Till Martyrdom Do Us Part' Gender and the ISIS Phenomenon |date=2015 |publisher=Institute for Strategic Dialogue |page=4|url=http://www.strategicdialogue.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Till_Martyrdom_Do_Us_Part_Gender_and_the_ISIS_Phenomenon.pdf|accessdate=25 February 2016 }}</ref>—part of what some<ref>Thomas Hegghammer, an expert on Islamist militancy affiliated with the Norwegian Defence Research Establishment (source: {{cite journal|last1=GILSINAN |first1=KATHY |title=The ISIS Crackdown on Women, by Women |journal=The Atlantic |date=25 July 2014 |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2014/07/the-women-of-isis/375047/|accessdate=25 February 2016}})</ref> have called "a jihadi, girl-power subculture".<ref name="isowbw">{{cite journal|last1=GILSINAN |first1=KATHY |title=The ISIS Crackdown on Women, by Women |journal=The Atlantic |date=25 July 2014 |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2014/07/the-women-of-isis/375047/|accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref>
==Background== The three girls had been questioned by the police in December 2014 after another girl from their school travelled to Syria, but were found not to be at risk.<ref name=bbc/> They flew via [[Turkish Airlines]] from [[Gatwick Airport]], London, to [[Istanbul]] on 17 February.<ref name=bbc>{{cite news|title=Syria girls: Families 'cannot stop crying'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-31575908|accessdate=7 April 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=22 February 2015}}</ref> Their families went to Turkey in March to probe the disappearance, deeming the police investigation inadequate.<ref>{{cite news|title=Isil defector girls' families go to Turkey to probe disappearance|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/11491142/Isil-defector-girls-families-go-to-Turkey-to-probe-disappearance.html|accessdate=7 April 2015|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=23 March 2015}}</ref>
Their disappearance has been attributed to Aqsa Mahmood, a [[Glasgow]] woman who joined ISIL in 2013. There have been electronic communications between the girls and Mahmood.<ref name=bbc/> She faces criminal charges if she returns.<ref>{{cite news|title=Scots jihadi will be prosecuted if she comes home, say police|url=http://news.stv.tv/west-central/313329-scots-jihadi-aqsa-mahmood-will-be-prosecuted-if-she-comes-home-say-police/|accessdate=7 April 2015|publisher=STV|date=10 March 2015}}</ref> Mahmood denies the allegations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cook|first1=James|title=Glasgow 'jihadist' Aqsa Mahmood denies recruiting London girls|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-31908202|accessdate=7 April 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=16 March 2015}}</ref>
In March 2015, footage was circulated of Abase Hussen, father of Amira Abase, on a 2012 rally led by Islamist preacher [[Anjem Choudary]] against the film ''[[Innocence of Muslims]]''. The [[Metropolitan Police]] examined the footage but said that it was unlikely that offences had been committed.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Morgan|first1=Ben|title=Jihadi schoolgirl's father marched at flag-burning rally|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/jihadi-schoolgirls-father-marched-at-flagburning-rally-anjem-choudary-10138591.html|accessdate=7 April 2015|work=London Evening Standard|date=27 March 2015}}</ref> Hussen said in April that he feels ashamed of his involvement in the rally, as he did not know who had organised it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Father of schoolgirl feared to have joined Islamic State denies 'extremism' claim|url=http://www.itv.com/news/london/2015-04-07/father-of-schoolgirl-feared-to-have-joined-islamic-state-denies-extremism-claim/|accessdate=7 April 2015|work=ITV News|date=7 April 2015}}</ref>
The girls stole family jewellery to pay for their flight. They will not face criminal charges if they return to the United Kingdom.<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|last1=Barrett|first1=David|title=Three 'Jihadi brides' from London who travelled to Syria will not face terrorism charges if they return|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/11461693/Sisters-of-the-missing-jihadi-brides-to-face-radicalisation-tests.html|accessdate=7 April 2015|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=10 March 2015}}</ref>
==Aftermath== The disappearance resulted in the Metropolitan Police giving evidence to the [[Home Affairs Select Committee]] of the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] on its circumstances in March 2015.<ref name=telegraph/> The families of the girls received an apology from [[Scotland Yard]], who did not tell them about the other girl from their school who went to Syria in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Nigel|title=Police sorry for failure to warn families of Isis girls about schoolfriend's flight|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=11415790|accessdate=7 April 2015|work=The New Zealand Herald|date=12 March 2015}}</ref>
British Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] has said that police should not be made "scapegoats" for people joining ISIL.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leaders: Vigilance crucial or more will be lost to IS|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/leaders-vigilance-crucial-or-more-will-be-lost-to-is-1-3715147|accessdate=7 April 2015|work=The Scotsman|date=10 March 2015}}</ref> Contrary to the stance of the Metropolitan Police, Cameron said "Whoever has gone out to join a terrorist organisation is breaking the law and has to face the consequences of breaking the law and we have to let the law take its course in the proper way".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Beake|first1=Nick|title=David Cameron concerned over Syria-bound London girls|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-32134575|accessdate=7 April 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=31 March 2015}}</ref>
In March 2015, a travel ban was imposed upon five girls from the Bethnal Green Academy due to concerns from social services that they the girls attend the same school as the three who had already joined the group, stating that it was in the public interest.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bowcott|first1=Owen|title=Travel ban for five east London girls over fears they will join Isis in Syria|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/mar/27/five-girls-barred-from-travel-same-school-three-teenagers-syria-bethnal-green-academy|accessdate=7 April 2015|work=The Guardian|date=27 March 2015}}</ref>
The teenagers have not made contact with their families since May 2016. Begum was reported to have married an American jihadist recruit who left her once she became pregnant. Sultana is said to have married a western ISIS fighter with Somali heritage, but wanted to return to the UK after he was killed in battle. Shortly afterwards she was killed in a Russian airstrike.<ref name="standard">{{cite news |last=De Peyer|first=Robin|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/world/families-fear-bethnal-green-schoolgirls-who-travelled-to-join-isis-are-now-dead-a3605096.html|title=Families fear Bethnal Green schoolgirls who travelled to join Isis are now dead|work= |location=London|publisher=''[[London Evening Standard]]''|date=6 August 2017|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> Sultana's family in a phone interview with ITV in August 2016 said that they believed her to have died in an airstrike in May 2016 at the age of 17 while planning to escape.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Henley|first1=Jon|last2=Dodd|first2=Vikram|title=Kadiza Sultana: London schoolgirl who joined Isis believed killed in Syria airstrike|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/aug/11/london-schoolgirl-kadiza-sultana-who-joined-isis-believed-killed-in-syria-airstrike|accessdate=12 August 2016|work=The Guardian|date=12 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Veselinovic|first1=Milena|last2=McKenzie|first2=Sheena|title=Family fears British girl who went to Syria is dead|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/08/11/middleeast/uk-isis-missing-girls/|accessdate=12 August 2016|work=The Guardian|date=14 August 2016}}</ref> The lawyer who represents the family of the teenagers Tasnime Akunjee told ITV that she became too scared of making an escape attempt after another girl [[Samra Kesinovic]] was beaten to death for trying to escape.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dearden|first1=Lizzie|title=Isis jihadi bride Kadiza Sultana 'abandoned efforts to escape Syria after Austrian girl beaten to death'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/isis-latest-syria-british-bride-kadiza-sultana-killed-air-strike-death-gave-up-after-girl-beaten-a7186661.html|accessdate=13 August 2016|work=The Independent|date=14 August 2016}}</ref> Abase married an 18-year-old Australian jihadist, Abdullah Elmir in July 2016 who was reported by Australian intelligence agencies to have been killed in coalition airstrikes. After the teenagers married foreign jihadists, they moved into the homes of their new husbands in ISIL' de facto capital of [[Raqqa]].<ref name="opride">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://www.opride.com/2017/12/04/3286/|title=Families fear Bethnal Green schoolgirls who travelled to join Isis are now dead|work= |location= |publisher=''OPride.com''|date=4 December 2017|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref>

{{Plainlist| * Michelle Knight * Amanda Berry * Georgina "Gina" DeJesus }} | perp = {{Plainlist| * Ariel Castro }} }} The '''Ariel Castro kidnappings''' took place between 2002 and 2004 when three young women — Michelle Knight, Amanda Berry, and Georgina "Gina" DeJesus — were kidnapped by Ariel Castro and held captive in his home in the [[Tremont, Cleveland|Tremont]] neighborhood of [[Cleveland]], in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Ohio]]. They were subsequently imprisoned until May 6, 2013, when Berry escaped with her six-year-old daughter and contacted the police.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/frantic-911-call-leads-3-missing-women-ohio |title=Police Facing Questions in 3 Women's Ohio Rescue |last1=Sheeran |first1=Thomas |last2=Coyne |first2=John archivedate = May 8, 2013 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Knight and DeJesus were rescued by responding officers and Castro was arrested within hours.
On May 8, 2013, Castro was charged with four counts of [[kidnapping]] and three counts of [[rape]].<ref name="plain-dealer-charges">{{Cite news | last = Caniglia | first = John | last2 = Blackwell | first2 = Brandon | date = May 9, 2013 | title = Cleveland city prosecutors charge Ariel Castro with kidnapping, rape in case of missing women | newspaper = [[The Plain Dealer]] | publisher = Cleveland Live LLC, [[Advance Publications]] | publication-place = Cleveland, OH | url = http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/cleveland_city_prosecutors_cha.html#incart_river#incart_maj-story-1 | accessdate = May 16, 2013 | format = news article posted to Cleveland.com | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130510123113/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/cleveland_city_prosecutors_cha.html#incart_river | archivedate = May 10, 2013 | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/cleveland-kidnapping-suspect-ariel-castro-hid-dark-side/story?id=19122845 |title=Cleveland Kidnapping Suspect Ariel Castro Hid a Dark Side, His Uncle Says |last1=Perez |first1=Alex |date=May 7, 2013 |publisher=ABC News |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508090308/http://abcnews.go.com/US/cleveland-kidnapping-suspect-ariel-castro-hid-dark-side/story?id=19122845 |archivedate=May 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Castro pleaded guilty to 937 criminal counts of rape, kidnapping, and [[Aggravation (law)|aggravated murder]] as part of a [[plea bargain]]. He was sentenced to life plus 1,000 years in prison without the possibility of parole.<ref name=usat072613>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/07/26/ariel-castro-cleveland-abduction-plea-deal-death-penalty/2589039/ |title=Ariel Castro pleads guilty in Ohio abductions |last1=Stanglin |first1=Doug |newspaper=USA Today |date=July 26, 2013 |accessdate=July 26, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130726170640/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/07/26/ariel-castro-cleveland-abduction-plea-deal-death-penalty/2589039/ |archivedate=July 26, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ariel-castro-michelle-knight-20130801,0,2844274.story |last=Muskal |first=Michael |title=Ariel Castro gets life, no parole; victim says his hell awaits |publisher=latimes.com |accessdate=September 4, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130911223531/http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ariel-castro-michelle-knight-20130801,0,2844274.story |archivedate=September 11, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> One month into his sentence, Castro committed suicide by hanging himself with bedsheets in his prison cell.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.10tv.com/content/stories/2013/09/04/Pickaway_Castro_Death.html |date=September 4, 2013 |publisher=10TV.com |title=Cleveland Kidnapper Ariel Castro Dead After Found Hanging In Prison Cell |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6JNhWbTEq?url=http://www.10tv.com/content/stories/2013/09/04/Pickaway_Castro_Death.html |archivedate=September 4, 2013 |accessdate=September 4, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref><ref name="suiciderpt"/>
==Perpetrator background== Ariel Castro was born on July 11, 1960, in [[Yauco, Puerto Rico|Yauco]], [[Puerto Rico]], to Pedro Castro and Lillian Rodriguez. When he was a child, his parents divorced. Shortly after the divorce, Castro moved to the [[contiguous United States|mainland]] with his mother and three siblings. The family first settled in [[Reading, Pennsylvania|Reading]], [[Pennsylvania]], and later moved to [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], where Castro's father and several other extended family members were living.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latintimes.com/articles/4018/20130515/ariel-castro-relatives-puerto-rico-evil-demon-reading-cleveland.htm |title=Ariel Castro Relatives In Puerto Rico Say He Is Castro met his future girlfriend, Grimilda Figueroa, when his family moved into a house across the street from hers in the 1980s. They lived with both sets of parents, but moved into their own home at 2207 Seymour Avenue in 1992.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/08/us/ohio-missing-women-found/ |title=Ohio 1956.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/07/missing-women-cleveland-brothers-arrested/2140359/ |title=Reports of sex abuse, beatings inside Cleveland house }}</ref><ref name=csm>{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/USA-Update/2013/0508/Three-brothers-arrested-what-s-known-so-far-about-alleged-Cleveland-captors |title=Three brothers arrested: |archivedate=May 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> According to Figueroa's sister, Elida Caraballo, when the couple moved into their new home, "all hell started breaking loose". Caraballo and her husband Frank claim Castro beat Figueroa, breaking her nose, ribs, and arms. He also threw her down a flight of stairs, cracking her skull.<ref name="nationalpost1"/> In 1993, Castro was arrested for [[domestic violence]] but was not [[indictment|indicted]] by a [[grand jury]].<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/tv_station_reports_berry_dejes.html |title=Berry, DeJesus, Knight found alive, police source confirms |last1=Atassi |first1=Leila |date=May 7, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6GyIyu?url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/tv_station_reports_berry_dejes.html |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Figueroa moved out of the home in 1996 and secured custody of her four children. Police assisted in the move and detained Castro, but did not pursue charges.<ref name="nationalpost1" /> Castro continued to threaten and attack Figueroa after she left him, according to Caraballo. A 2005 filing by Figueroa in [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio|Cuyahoga County]] [[Family court|Domestic Relations Court]] accused Castro of inflicting multiple severe injuries on her and of "frequently abduct[ing]" her daughters. A [[Injunction|temporary restraining order]] against Castro was granted, but was dismissed a few months later.<ref name="nationalpost1" /> Figueroa died in 2012 due to complications from a [[brain tumor]].<ref name="nationalpost1" />

===Michelle Knight=== Michelle Knight (born April 23, 1981) disappeared on August 23, 2002, after leaving a cousin's house.<ref name=pd050713>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/michelle_knight_plagued_by_tro.html |title=Michelle Knight's 'normal teenage life,' plagued by troubles in years before disappearance |last1=Atassi |first1=Leila |date=May 7, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6Bph5C?url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/michelle_knight_plagued_by_tro.html |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> She was 21 years old at the time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kpho.com/story/22184761/questions-still-remain-about-michelle-knights-disappearance |title=Questions still remain about Michelle Knight's disappearance |date=May 7, 2013 |publisher=KPHO |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6DDqHI?url=http://www.kpho.com/story/22184761/questions-still-remain-about-michelle-knights-disappearance |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> On the day of her disappearance, she was scheduled to appear in court for a [[child custody]] case involving her son, who was in the custody of the state.<ref name=pd050713/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/09/michelle-knight-cleveland-abduction/2149003/ |title=Reports: Knight lived troubled life before abduction |last1=Eversley |first1=Melanie |last2=Alcindor |first2=Yamiche |date=May 9, 2013 |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6EBJwz?url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/09/michelle-knight-cleveland-abduction/2149003/ |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Following Knight's rescue, police acknowledged that limited resources had been spent on investigating her disappearance, in part because she was an adult. Knight was believed to have run away voluntarily due to anger over losing custody of her son. According to Cleveland Deputy Police Chief Ed Tomba, she "was the focus of very few tips".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/05/07/18108362-police-acknowledge-little-focus-on-finding-michelle-knight-the-third-missing-cleveland-woman?lite |title=Police acknowledge little focus on finding Michelle Knight, the third missing Cleveland woman |last1=Johnson |first1=M. Alex |date=May 7, 2013 |publisher=NBC News |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6F13gS?url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/05/07/18108362-police-acknowledge-little-focus-on-finding-michelle-knight-the-third-missing-cleveland-woman?lite |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Her removal from the [[National Crime Information Center]] database fifteen months after she disappeared has been criticized. [[Cleveland Division of Police|Cleveland Police]] and the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] maintain that her inclusion or exclusion had no bearing on her rescue.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/michelle_knight_held_captive_f.html |title=Michelle Knight, held captive since 2002, removed by Cleveland police from FBI database 15 months after her disappearance |last1=Atassi |first1=Leila |date=May 9, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6GBBzy?url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/michelle_knight_held_captive_f.html |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Amanda Berry=== Amanda Marie Berry (born April 22, 1986) disappeared on April 21, 2003, the day before her 17th birthday.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22433057 |title=Profile: Amanda Berry, Georgina DeJesus and Michele Knight |date=May 7, 2013 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6J4MVu?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22433057 |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> She was last heard from when she called her sister to tell her that she was getting a ride home from her job at a [[Burger King]] at West 110th Street and [[Ohio State Route 10|Lorain Avenue]].<ref name= newsnet5-found /> The FBI initially considered Berry a [[Runaway (dependent)|runaway]] until a week after her disappearance, when an unidentified male used her cell phone to call her mother, saying, "I have Amanda. She's fine and will be coming home in a couple of days".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/amanda_berrys_cell_phone_used.html |title=Amanda Berry's cell phone used a week after she went missing |last1=Guevara |first1=Damian |last2=Caniglia |first2=John |date=November 15, 2003 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6KYstD?url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/amanda_berrys_cell_phone_used.html |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2013/05/07/found-timeline-of-ohio-women-missing-since-2002/ |title=Found: Timeline of Ohio Women Missing Since 2002 |last1=Gray |first1=Madison |date=May 7, 2013 |newspaper=Time |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6LIBXd?url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2013/05/07/found-timeline-of-ohio-women-missing-since-2002/ |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Berry was featured in a 2004 segment of [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]'s ''[[America's Most Wanted]]'' (re-aired in 2005 and 2006), which linked her to Gina DeJesus, who by that point had also gone missing in Cleveland.<ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amw.com/missing_children/case.cfm?id=25773 |title=Amanda Berry |date=May 6, 2013 |publisher=America's Most Wanted |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510102825/http://www.amw.com/missing_children/case.cfm?id=25773 |archivedate=May 10, 2013 }}</ref> Berry and DeJesus were profiled on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' and ''[[The Montel Williams Show]]'', where in 2004 self-proclaimed psychic [[Sylvia Browne]] told Berry's mother, Louwana Miller, that her daughter was dead and that she was "in water".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/story.aspx?storyid=26501 |title=Amanda Berry's mother asks Psychic Sylvia Browne 'Is she out there' |date=November 18, 2004 |publisher=WKYC |accessdate=May 13, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/daughter-found-women-missing-decade/story?id=19122795 |title=Kidnap Victim Amanda Berry Hailed as 'Real Hero' in Rescue of Three Women |last1=Goldman |first1=Russell |last2=Dolak |first2=Kevin |last3=Muir |first3=David |last4=Castellano |first4=Anthony |date=May 7, 2013 |publisher=ABC News |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508083940/http://abcnews.go.com/US/daughter-found-women-missing-decade/story?id=19122795 |archivedate=May 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2013/05/07/psychic-on-the-montel-williams-show-said-amanda-berry-was-dead/ |title=Psychic on The Montel Williams Show said Amanda Berry was dead. She wasn't. |last1=Senger |first1=Emily |date=May 7, 2013 |publisher=Maclean's |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513043608/http://www2.macleans.ca/2013/05/07/psychic-on-the-montel-williams-show-said-amanda-berry-was-dead/ |archivedate=May 13, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oprah.com/oprahshow/Abductions-of-Amanda-Berry-Gina-DeJesus-and-Ashley-Summers-Video |title=The Abductions of Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus & Ashley Summers This pronouncement devastated her mother, causing her to take down pictures and give away Berry's computer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/amanda_berry_is_dead_psychic_t.html |title=Amanda Berry is dead, psychic tells her mother on Montel Williams' show |last1=Hudak |first1=Stephen In July 2012, Robert Wolford, a prison inmate who previously lived in Tremont, claimed to have information about the location of Berry's body and led police to an empty lot on Cleveland's West Side, where a fruitless search was conducted.<ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref name="3 missing women found">{{cite news |author1=Sheeran, Thomas J. |author2=Coyne, John |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2-women-missing-decade-found-alive-ohio |title=3 missing women found in Ohio, 3 brothers arrested |agency=Associated Press |date=May 7, 2013 |accessdate=May 14, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6azULh?url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2-women-missing-decade-found-alive-ohio |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Wolford was sentenced in January 2013 to four-and-a-half years in prison for [[obstruction of justice]], [[making false statements|making a false report]], and making a false alarm.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/ohio-inmate-robert-wolford-gets-4-years-in-false-amanda-berry-search-tip |title=Ohio inmate Robert Wolford gets 4 years in false Amanda Berry search tip |date=January 16, 2013 |publisher=newsnet5.com |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130507132144/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/ohio-inmate-robert-wolford-gets-4-years-in-false-amanda-berry-search-tip |archivedate=May 7, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On December 25, 2006, Berry gave birth to a daughter <!-- Please do not add the daughter's name, see talk page for more details. --> at 2207 Seymour Avenue.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/10047663/Ohio-kidnappings-Michelle-Knight-forced-to-deliver-Amanda-Berrys-baby-on-Christmas-Day.html |title=Ohio kidnappings: Michelle Knight forced to deliver Amanda Berry's baby on Christmas Day |last1=Swaine |first1=Jon |date=May 9, 2013 |newspaper=The Telegraph |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511210935/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/10047663/Ohio-kidnappings-Michelle-Knight-forced-to-deliver-Amanda-Berrys-baby-on-Christmas-Day.html |archivedate=May 11, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> DNA evidence has confirmed that Castro was the biological father of the child.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/ariel_castro_is_father_of_aman.html |title=Ariel Castro is father of Amanda Berry's child, state DNA results say |date=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607110711/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/ariel_castro_is_father_of_aman.html |archivedate=June 7, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/298935/45/Investigator-Ariel-Castro-says-hes-cold-blooded |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615084817/http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/298935/45/Investigator-Ariel-Castro-says-hes-cold-blooded |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 15, 2013 |title=Investigator: Ariel Castro says he's "cold blooded" |last1=Meyer |first1=Tom |date=May 10, 2013 |publisher=WKYC |accessdate=May 13, 2013 }}</ref>
===Gina DeJesus=== [[Image:Gina-suspect-sketch.jpg|thumb|upright|right|180px|2004 FBI sketch of a suspect in DeJesus' disappearance]] Georgina "Gina" Lynn DeJesus (born February 13, 1990) went missing at age 14.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.cleveland.com/pdextra/2008/04/six_long_days_gina_still_missi.html |title=Six long days, Gina still missing Parents, police, city officials focus on case at community meeting |last1=Zicari |first1=Peter |date=April 1, 2008 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20130517194140/http://blog.cleveland.com/pdextra/2008/04/six_long_days_gina_still_missi.html |archivedate=May 17, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> She was last seen at a [[payphone]] at about 3 p.m. on April 2, 2004, on the way home from her [[middle school]] at West 105th Street and Lorain Avenue. DeJesus and her friend, Castro's daughter Arlene, had called Figueroa for permission to have a sleepover at DeJesus's house, but Figueroa replied they could not and the two girls parted ways.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/suspects_daughter_said_in_2004.html |title=Suspect's daughter said in 2004 she was the last to see Gina DeJesus |last1=Dissell |first1=Rachel |date=May 7, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk6Vrz5i?url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/05/suspects_daughter_said_in_2004.html |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Arlene was the last person to see DeJesus before her disappearance.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/cleveland-kidnapping-latest-police-twice-visited-house-in-ohio--but-missed-three-women-held-captive-for-a-decade-8605381.html |title=Cleveland kidnapping: Son reveals his father padlocked doors to basement because 'we weren't allowed to go there' |last1=Kumar |first1=Nikhil |last2=Usborne |first2=David |date=May 8, 2013 |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508011422/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/cleveland-kidnapping-latest-police-twice-visited-house-in-ohio--but-missed-three-women-held-captive-for-a-decade-8605381.html |archivedate=May 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
DeJesus was taken under the impression that she was being dropped off, and trusted Castro because she was friends with his teenage daughter. Because no one witnessed DeJesus's abduction, an [[AMBER Alert]] was not issued, which angered DeJesus's father. He said in 2006, "The Amber Alert should work for any missing child … Whether it's an abduction or a runaway, a child needs to be found. We need to change this law".<ref name="3 missing women found"/>
A year after DeJesus' disappearance, the FBI released a [[composite sketch]] and description of a male suspect, described as "Latino, 25 to 35 years of age, {{convert|5|ft|10|in}}, {{convert|165|to|185|lb}}, with green eyes, a [[goatee]] and possibly a pencil-thin beard".<ref>{{cite web |last=Swaine |first=Jon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/10045464/Ohio-abductions-FBI-photofit-with-likeness-to-suspect-Ariel-Castro-held-for-seven-years-as-police-say-he-acted-alone.html |title=Ohio abductions: FBI photofit with likeness to suspect Ariel Castro held for seven years as police say he acted alone |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=May 9, 2013 |accessdate=September 4, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130608063305/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/10045464/Ohio-abductions-FBI-photofit-with-likeness-to-suspect-Ariel-Castro-held-for-seven-years-as-police-say-he-acted-alone.html |archivedate=June 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> According to court records, Castro was {{convert|5|ft|7|in}}, {{convert|179|lb}}; he had brown eyes and a goatee.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/story.aspx?storyid=33093 |title=Printout: FBI releases sketch of Gina DeJesus' alleged kidnapper |date=April 15, 2005 |publisher=WKYC |accessdate=May 13, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10882714 |title=FBI had sketch of suspect but missed the connection |date=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |accessdate=May 13, 2013}}</ref>
DeJesus was featured in the aforementioned ''America's Most Wanted'' segment, which linked her to Berry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amw.com/missing_children/case.cfm?id=26744 |title=Gina DeJesus |date=May 6, 2013 |publisher=America's Most Wanted |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130609014439/http://www.amw.com/missing_children/case.cfm?id=26744 |archivedate=June 9, 2013 }}</ref> The disappearances received regular media attention over the years, continuing into 2012, while the families held public [[vigil]]s. Castro attended at least two of these vigils,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://globalnews.ca/video/542366/extended-interview-with-family-of-kidnapping-victim-gina-dejesus/ |title=Extended: Interview with
